title.narrative: COVID-19 WFP - UNICEF Joint Programme on Social Protection in Uganda 2019-2023
COVID-19 WFP - UNICEF gemensamt program social trygghet i Uganda 2019-2023

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 WFP i samarbete med UNICEF har ansökt till Sida om 477 000 000 SEK (49 499 474 USD) i stöd för att genomföra programmet "Child-Sensitive Social Protection in Refugee-Hosting Districts of West Nile, Uganda" under perioden 2019-2024.
Programmet syftar till ökad motståndskraft och social trygghet, förbättrad hälsa och nutrition för utsatta barn och mödrar i West Nile i norra Uganda.
Den övergripande inriktningen på programmet är att stärka och komplettera existerande nationella program och system för social trygghet och hälsa med fokus på att göra dessa system mer effektiva och mer inriktade på att motverka barns utsatthet och främja bättre nutrition. Programmet förväntas göra pågående stöd mer hållbara och ta tillvara synergier genom att utnyttja resurser från befintliga nationella program, basservice och system för att nå starkare resultat för resiliens, hälsa och nutrition.
Programmets övergripande mål är stärkt ekonomisk inkludering av hushåll, förbättrad hälsa och nutrition för mödrar och barn. Det är inriktat på nexus mellan humanitärt stöd och långsiktigt utvecklingssamarbete genom att stärka införlivandet av flyktingar i existerande nationella system för hälsa och social trygghet.
Programmet syftar till att nå effekter på två nivåer; direkt för målgruppen, samt på systemnivå. Effekter på systemnivå förväntas uppnås genom att programmet bidrar till mer effektiva och transparenta system för social trygghet och hälsa med stärkt barn-perspektiv och ökad nutritionskänslighet.
Stödet till systemnivå länkas till pågående program för social trygghet (såsom SAGE - Social Assistance Grants for Empowerment, NUSAF3 - Northern Uganda Social Assistance Fund och DRDIP - Development Response to Displacement Impacts Project) och förväntas åtgärda brister i systemen för hälsovård och social trygghet.
Dialoginsatser riktade till målgruppen ska stärka efterfrågan på hälsovård och bidra till förändrat beteende som stärker resiliens, hälsa och nutrition.
De planerade effekterna för målgruppen är: - Ökad eller mer tillförlitlig inkomst genom kontantstöd - Förbättrad tillgång till marknader med lägre priser och högre variation på livsmedel - Mer varierad diet för hushållen - Förbättrad tillgång till kvalitativ hälsovård - Förbättrad efterfrågan på hälsovård
Programmet administreras av WFP genom ett standardavtal "Standard Administrative Agreement (SAA) for joint UN programmes" och implementeras av WFP och UNICEF i samarbete med lokala aktörer och ansvariga ministerier för social trygghet och hälsa. Det systemstärkande stödet bygger på pågående insatser av UNICEF och WFP för att stärka hälsosystemet, ge humanitärt stöd till flyktingar och stärka systemet för social trygghet. Det föreslagna stödet kompletterar pågående humanitärt stöd från WFP till flyktingar och bidrar till att utveckla mer hållbara lösningar i den långvariga humanitära situationen. Pågående stöd från UNICEF för att stärka hälsosystem och hälsotjänster kommer att införlivas i det föreslagna programmet som kommer vara mer integrerat och holistiskt.
En ny aspekt i programmet är komponenten för social trygghet med förmedling av kontantstöd till mottagare. Det förväntas bidra till effektiv fattigdomsminskning för sårbara hushåll och ge en förbättrad situation för både flyktingar och värdbefolkning vilket kan minska spänningar i dessa samhällen där risken för konflikt över otillräckliga resurser och samhällsservice har ökat efter det stora flyktingmottagandet. Programmet syftar också till påverka marknader för att öka tillgång till och variation av näringsrika varor till lägre priser.
Jämställdhetsperspektivet integreras tydligt i insatsen och en fördjupad analys kommer göras under det första året av kopplingen mellan jämställdhet, funktionshinder, hälsa och nutrition i de valda distrikten.
Programmet genomförs med en flexibel ansats där genomförandet utvecklas och anpassas i nära samarbete med nyckelaktörer i statliga strukturer på nationell och lokal nivå för att säkerställa hållbarhet. Den integrerade insatsen där WFP och UNICEF samarbetar förväntas också bidra till ökad effektivitet, kvalitet och långsiktig hållbarhet.
Stödet till systemen för social trygghet och hälsovård kompletteras av implementeringsforskning som både stödjer genomförandet av programmet och bidrar till kvalitativt, evidensbaserat, lärande. Detta förväntas bidra till att stödja den långsiktiga utvecklingen av systemen för social trygghet och hälsovård i Uganda.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 WFP in cooperation with UNICEF has applied to Sida for 477 000 000 SEK (49 499 474 USD) to support implementation of the programme "Child-Sensitive Social Protection in Refugee-Hosting Districts of West Nile, Uganda" during the period 2019-2024.
The programme aims to achieve increased resilience and social protection, improved health and nutrition for vulnerable children and mothers in West Nile. It has a focus on the nexus between humanitarian support and long-term development cooperation through strengthening the inclusion of refugees in existing national systems for health and social protection.
The overarching philosophy of the programme is to not create new programmes and systems, but to strengthen and complement existing, national social protection and health programmes and systems with a strong focus on making such systems more efficient and effective and more child- and nutrition-sensitive. This approach seeks not only to make program results sustainable, but also to help leverage the efforts and resources of these national programmes, services and systems to achieve enhanced results, in particular in terms of resilience, health and nutrition.
The programme objectives are improved economic inclusion of households, improved maternal and child nutrition and improved maternal and child health. Programme outcomes are pursued at two levels; the level of direct beneficiaries of programme activities and the level of systems.
The programme aims to affect the systems level through achieving more efficient, transparent, child- and nutrition-sensitive social protection systems as well as more efficient child- and nutrition-sensitive health systems.
The systems-strengthening support will link to ongoing social protection programmes (such as SAGE, Social Assistance Grants for Empowerment, NUSAF3, Northern Uganda Socail Assistance Fund, DRDIP, Development Response to Displacement Impacts Project) and will cover essential gaps in current health care and social protection systems.
Behavioural change communication directed to beneficiaries will support increased demand for services and changed behaviour that improves resilience, health and nutrition.
The outcomes for targeted beneficiaries will be: - Increased or more secure income, through cash transfers - Improved access to markets, with lower prices and higher diversity - Improved dietary diversity - Improved access to quality health services - Improved health-seeking behaviour
The programme will be administrated by WFP under a Standard Administrative Agreement (SAA) for joint UN programmes and implemented by WFP and UNICEF in cooperation with local actors and government ministries in social protection and health. The systems level support builds on ongoing interventions by UNICEF and WFP focusing on health systems strengthening, humantiarian support to refugees and the social protection system. The proposed support will aim at complementing ongoing humanitarian support by WFP to refugees providing the basis for more long-term, durable solutions to the protracted humanitarian situation. Ongoing support by UNICEF to strengthen the health system and health services will be taken over by the proposed programme, which will have an integrated and more comprehensive approach to development.
The new aspect of the programme is the social protection component with direct cash transfers to beneficiaries. This component is expected to add to efficient poverty reduction for vulnerable households and to provide an improved situation for both refugees and the refugee hosting population which can decrease tension in these societies where the risk for conflicts over insufficient resources and services has increased after the refugee influx. The programme also aims to affect markets to achieve increased availability and diversity of essential goods at lower prices.
The gender perspective is clearly integrated in the programme and an in-depth analysis will be undertaken during the first year of the linkages between gender, disability, health and nutrition in the selected districts.
The programme will be implemented through a flexible approach, where implementation will be developed and adapted in close collaboration with key actors in existing government structures at national and local level to ensure sustainability. The integrated approach combining efforts of WFP and UNICEF is also expected to improve efficiency, quality and long-term sustainability.
The strengtening of social protection systems and health care systems will be followed by rigorous operational research that will support the implementation and provide qualitative learning for further development of social protection and health care systems. This is expected to support the long-term development of the social protection system and health care system in Uganda.

The overall objective of the programme is to achieve improved community and household resilience among refugees and host populations in refugee-hosting districts of West Nile. The overall objective is broken down into three specific programme objectives: - Improved economic inclusion of households- Improved maternal and child nutrition- Improved maternal, neonatal and child health These objectives are broken down in a number of outcomes on both beneficiary and system levels. Outcome 1.1 - Increased or more secure incomesOutcome 1.2 - Improved access to markets Outcome 1.3 - Improved dietary variation of households Outcome 1.4 - Improved access to health services Outcome 1.5 - Improved health seeking behaviourOutcome 2.1 - More efficient, transparent, child- and nutrition-sensitive social protection systems. Outcome 2.2 - More efficient, transparent, child- and nutrition sensitive health services The programme will deliver a number of results on output level in order to achieve the otcomes and overall objectives. - Support links with on-going Social Protection Programmes- Provide child sensitive household transfers- Support cash transfer mechanisms- Support beneficiary information and assistance management (BIAM)- Support retail markets- Support to feedback and complaints systems- Health system strengthening and support- Social Behaviour Change Communication for increased demand for health services There is also a component on operational research for continuous learning and improvement of social and health services Update September 2020The annual report for 2019 included a proposed revised results framework for the UNICEF-led component. The changes include a revised results nomenclature which in summary changes the semantics to an “Impact, Outcome, Output” structure. Secondly, there is a revision of some of the indicators to better align with the programme design, as well as with UNICEF’s Country Programme Document and approved UNICEF Rolling WorkPlans (2019-2020). UNICEF concludes that "despite the adjustments to the resultsframework, the programme’s implementation framework remains unchanged from what was originally envisioned and submitted by UNICEF in the approved ProgrammeDocument." The changes were approved by Sida in the feedback on the report sent on 29 June 2020 (archived).

tag.narrative: 2.1 - By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.

2.1 - Senast 2030 avskaffa hunger och garantera alla människor, i synnerhet de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer, inklusive små barn, tillgång till tillräckligt med säker och näringsrik mat året om.

2.2 - By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving, by 2025, the internationally agreed targets on stunting and wasting in children under 5 years of age, and address the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant and lactating women and older persons.

2.2 - Senast 2030 avskaffa alla former av undernäring, bland annat genom att senast 2025 nå de internationellt överenskomna målen i fråga om tillväxthämning och undervikt bland barn under fem år, samt tillgodose tonårsflickors, gravida och ammande kvinnors samt äldre personers näringsbehov.
3.1 - By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.

3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.

3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.

description.narrative: IntroductionThe analysis below is based on the annual narrative and financial report for 2019 (Aug-Dec) and follow-up of the implementation during the first half of 2020. The programme document outlined a very detailed/prescriptive list of activities to be carried out in the first year of programme implementation, while at the same time explicitly stating that the programme would apply a flexible approach to implementation. The latter would "allow the programme to pursue its objectives while being able to adapt to emerging developments, risks and opportunities". From the onset of implementation in August/September 2019 it was clear from the initial dialogue with WFP that they wanted to take a step back from the detailed plan for the social protection (SP) component. They proposed to apply their new corporate Country Capacity Strengthening (CCS) approach/methodology, to identify areas of intervention for systems and capacity strengthening. The rationale as described in the annual report is to "ensure a focused approach that delivers results and supports the growth of targeted institutions, to increase their capacity to perform new functions, or achieve more autonomy in continuous tasks. Applying this approach to redefine the focus of system strengthening interventions will contribute to greater sustainability and retention of the capacity developed and strengthened during the programme. One of the fundamental principles of the CCS approach is to be demand-driven and co-created with the institution that receives support." In the very early dialogue stage WFP sought even more far-reaching flexibility and Sida's endorsement to completely remove the transfer component. This was however seen as non-negotiable as it would fundamentally change the original idea of the programme to combine direct targeting of vulnerable refugees and host populations, with system strengthening activities. Being a new approach not only to the programme but also for WFP Uganda, it required time to be internalised by WFP and socialised with national and district government stakeholders, as well as with UNICEF and Sida. The adoption was however presented as instrumental to adjust some of the planned inception phase activities to ensure a robust and sustainable approach to the SP component while still adhering to the overall principles and objectives of the programme. The CCS approach was eventually endorsed by Sida at the kick-off meeting (Sida/WFP/UNICEF) held in November 2019. While introducing a new methodology, many of the planned inception activities are still relevant and have been incorporated within the application of the CCS-approach. The internalization and socialisation processes obviously consumed time not originally planned for. Furthermore the ensuing design process and implementation, requiring buy-in and rigorous consultations with stakeholders, took longer than anticipated. Altogether this resulted in rather substantial delays compared to the original timeline, but the current assessment is that in the end it will have been time worth spending. Summary of key results Component 1: Social Protection (WFP-led)As this component is is entirely new, key results are mostly process oriented and relate to key inception phase activities that lay the foundation for actual implementation of the cash transfers and the system strengthening activities to come. WFP focused on establishing effective partnerships with key stakeholders at national and district level; sharing and consolidating plans for the first year of the programme; and putting in place the team both at central and local levels. Consultations were held with the Ministry of Gender, Labour and Social Development (MGLSD), Office of the Prime Minister (OPM) and District Local Governments (DLGs) of West Nile refugee hosting districts on the joint programme and its objectives through meetings with the District Technical Planning Committee meetings, West Nile Development Association forum, and different Ministry technical briefings. On systems strengthening, the use of the CCS methodology led to the development of a roadmap for the formulation of a multi-year work plan for social protection systems strengthening. The roadmap was presented and agreed with UNICEF and Sida during the first months of the programme. The starting point of the CCS approach is a "capacity outcome statement" that highlights what capacity of which recipient agency is strengthened, by whom, where, how and why. The capacity outcome statement was adopted by OPM, MGLSD and WFP in extensive consultations with the OPM team (NUSAF3 and DRDIP) and MGLSD as the overall statement that will define the capacity needs engagement process. The roadmap outlines how WFP is facilitating government leadership to define the priority areas for intervention years two to five of the project. One critical milestone of this process is the capacity needs mapping that forms the basis to agree priority areas of interventions in a co-owned way. Due to Covid-19 containment measures and limitations to meetings, the consultation process to finalise the capacity needs mapping will be finalised in September (instead of June). WFP is leading the design and implementation of a nutrition- and child-sensitive cash transfer. To maximise linkages between the household transfer and the health system strengthening component, WFP agreed with UNICEF to leverage nutrition services and communication campaigns together with additional resources to support vulnerable households to afford a nutritious diet. Following this agreement, WFP has developed a roadmap to deliver a nutrition-sensitive cash transfer to refugees and host communities in coordination with UNICEF. Much of WFP’s resources will be devoted to the covid-19 reprogramming (see below) for the coming three to four months. During which, a minimal set of originally planned activities that can be done remotely will be worked on with an aim to resume full implementation by the end of 2020. This means that implementation of the cash transfer pilot and social protection system strengthening activities will begin from early 2021. Component 2: Health Package (UNICEF-led)The health package component implemented by UNICEF is to a large degree a continuation/extension of the ongoing project Improving Maternal, Newborn and Child Health through Integrated Approaches, implemented in West Nile, funded by Sida. Hence, this component has moved more straight into the implementation phase including delivery of services to the target population. Examples of outputs:- At the district level, out of an estimated annual burden of 9,430 children with Severe Acute Malnutrition, UNICEF supported the treatment of 4,304 children 6-59 months of age (45 per cent) in West Nile. Out of the total number, 3,273 were from refugee settlements with an average cure rate of 91 per cent. - The project was instrumental to improving the availability and quality of data for decision making. MoH was supported to update and disseminate health information management system (HMIS) reporting tools. Additionally, technical support was provided to DLGs through the implementing partner AVSI to strengthen districts’ capacity for data collection and reporting through HMIS. Across districts, this support has contributed to an average reporting rate of 92% (national average 75%). - To improve water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) in high volume health facilities, 30 health centres were prioritized for WASH upgrades in consultation with DLGs. Construction is ongoing (Sep 2020) and additional improvements are implemented under the other UNICEF contribution supported by Sida. - To address poor treatment outcomes arising from low retention of mother-baby pairs along the Prevention of Mother to Child Transmission of HIV (PMTCT) cascade, 19 Family Support Groups (FSG) were operationalized in Arua, Adjumani, Madi Okollo and Yumbe districts. FSGs are dedicated psychosocial support peer groups for PMTCT mother-baby pairs and their male partners. A total of 707 mother-baby pairs and their male partners with unsuppressed viral loads were identified and enrolled. Building on Sida's earlier and ongoing support to maternal and child health, UNICEF further articulated and initiated the operationalization of the District Health Systems Strengthening (DHSS) approach in all West Nile districts. The approach represents an important shift away from a more traditional one of “health systems support”, where the main emphasis has been on the provision of key inputs to address immediate service delivery gaps. As reported by UNICEF, initial implementation experience suggests that achieving this shift requires a clear strategy and operational approach, supported by sustained communication and resources; clear metrics to assess DHSS effectiveness; and strong partnerships with key stakeholders. Component 3: Cross-cutting (WFP and UNICEF)Cross cutting activities are implemented by WFP and UNICEF. WFP is designing support to local markets in parallel with the design of the nutrition-sensitive transfer, to ensure that a market engagement strategy supports the supply of nutritious food by local retailers. Activities foreseen to support national feedback and complaint mechanisms were absorbed by component 1 and included in the comprehensive capacity needs mapping. UNICEF’s cross-cutting linkages have been integrated into component 2 and progress on operational research includes the launch of a call for proposals to design an impact and economic evaluation of health systems strengthening efforts, and to implement a baseline and produce three to four analytical papers. Impact of COVID-19 and reprogramming of fundsBoth UNICEF and WFP have been affected in various ways, with the government’s containment measures leading to delays in the originally planned programme activities, due to the postponement of gatherings and restrictions to movements. Governance activities were delayed, as well as the development of a multi-year work plan and budget for component 1. As organizations well placed to contribute to the national response and mitigation efforts, both have also received Sida's approval for reprogramming of existing funding to address direct and indirect effects of the pandemic. See below for more information on the reprogramming. UNICEF specificThe approved reallocation of USD 846,000 supports two intervention streams: 1) emergency response for containment and management of Covid-19 (through coordination, risk communication and community engagement, infection prevention and control, mental health and psycho social support, and communication), and 2) the mitigation of the unintended consequences of containment measures (support access to essential services and life-saving goods like, health, nutrition, HIV and WASH). The proposed use of funds is aligned with the National Covid-19 Response Plan for Health Sector and the UNICEF Uganda COVID-19 Response Plan. The risk of Covid-19 negatively impacting the originally planned programme results were assessed by UNICEF as moderate and they commit to minimizing the impact on programme results and notify WFP and Sida if the continued impact of the epidemic jeopardizes expected outcomes. WFP specificThe Embassy was early on in dialogue with WFP about possibilities for reprogramming. The initial plan was a one-off emergency transfer to persons aged 65+ in the West Nile region where the current programme is implemented. It would align with/mirror the existing Senior Citizens Grant (today targeting 80+) and reach both refugees and the host population. The interaction with the government complicated matters however. The dialogue with the line ministry for social protection, Ministry of Gender Labour & Social Development, was constructive but beyond that, social protection was not at the time considered either an essential service or key element of the national response to COVID19. Eventually the Ministry of Finance shut down any proposals put forward by partners that wanted to expand existing programmes horizontally and/or included unconditional cash transfers and chose to focus on labour intensive public works interventions (LIPW) instead. This in spite of overwhelming evidence that unconditional cash is more effective and efficient in an emergency situation. This resulted in a tweaked approach in order to maintain an element of unconditional transfers to support those more at risk of contracting and developing severe symptoms of Covid-19. The approved reallocation of USD 4,2m entails a one-off emergency cash transfer to 117,000 pregnant and lactating women and children under 2 currently covered by three programmes in the refugee hosting districts in West Nile: WFP’s maternal and child health nutrition programme and the government implemented DRDIP and NUSAF labour intensive public works programmes. However, the transfer is delivered by WFP and clearly communicated as an emergency measure. Within the guiding principle of the joint programme, that seeks to align humanitarian response and social assistance, the transfer targets the Ugandan population and refugees with the same demographic characteristics. Given the ration cuts in the humanitarian refugee response, this emergency assistance contributes to the food security of a vulnerable group and will quickly provide financial assistance to a significant proportion of the population. It will reach the groups most in need while leveraging existing government programmes. Importantly, the reprogramming also provides an opportunity to test arrangements and draw important lessons for the planned nutrition-sensitive cash transfer pilot. Financial managementAs a result of underspending in 2019 the 2020 budget was revised in March for absorption of unspent funds. The budget revision was done in close consultation with Sida through several meetings including the project's first Steering Committee meeting that was held in February. An updated multi-year workplan and budget will be presented to Sida in September 2020 for review ahead of the second Steering Committee meeting in October.The next payment of SEK 50,000,000 is planned for September.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 WFP in cooperation with UNICEF has applied to Sida for 477 000 000 SEK (49 499 474 USD) to support implementation of the programme "Child-Sensitive Social Protection in Refugee-Hosting Districts of West Nile, Uganda" during the period 2019-2024.
The programme aims to achieve increased resilience and social protection, improved health and nutrition for vulnerable children and mothers in West Nile. It has a focus on the nexus between humanitarian support and long-term development cooperation through strengthening the inclusion of refugees in existing national systems for health and social protection.
The overarching philosophy of the programme is to not create new programmes and systems, but to strengthen and complement existing, national social protection and health programmes and systems with a strong focus on making such systems more efficient and effective and more child- and nutrition-sensitive. This approach seeks not only to make program results sustainable, but also to help leverage the efforts and resources of these national programmes, services and systems to achieve enhanced results, in particular in terms of resilience, health and nutrition.
The programme objectives are improved economic inclusion of households, improved maternal and child nutrition and improved maternal and child health. Programme outcomes are pursued at two levels; the level of direct beneficiaries of programme activities and the level of systems.
The programme aims to affect the systems level through achieving more efficient, transparent, child- and nutrition-sensitive social protection systems as well as more efficient child- and nutrition-sensitive health systems.
The systems-strengthening support will link to ongoing social protection programmes (such as SAGE, Social Assistance Grants for Empowerment, NUSAF3, Northern Uganda Socail Assistance Fund, DRDIP, Development Response to Displacement Impacts Project) and will cover essential gaps in current health care and social protection systems.
Behavioural change communication directed to beneficiaries will support increased demand for services and changed behaviour that improves resilience, health and nutrition.
The outcomes for targeted beneficiaries will be: - Increased or more secure income, through cash transfers - Improved access to markets, with lower prices and higher diversity - Improved dietary diversity - Improved access to quality health services - Improved health-seeking behaviour
The programme will be administrated by WFP under a Standard Administrative Agreement (SAA) for joint UN programmes and implemented by WFP and UNICEF in cooperation with local actors and government ministries in social protection and health. The systems level support builds on ongoing interventions by UNICEF and WFP focusing on health systems strengthening, humantiarian support to refugees and the social protection system. The proposed support will aim at complementing ongoing humanitarian support by WFP to refugees providing the basis for more long-term, durable solutions to the protracted humanitarian situation. Ongoing support by UNICEF to strengthen the health system and health services will be taken over by the proposed programme, which will have an integrated and more comprehensive approach to development.
The new aspect of the programme is the social protection component with direct cash transfers to beneficiaries. This component is expected to add to efficient poverty reduction for vulnerable households and to provide an improved situation for both refugees and the refugee hosting population which can decrease tension in these societies where the risk for conflicts over insufficient resources and services has increased after the refugee influx. The programme also aims to affect markets to achieve increased availability and diversity of essential goods at lower prices.
The gender perspective is clearly integrated in the programme and an in-depth analysis will be undertaken during the first year of the linkages between gender, disability, health and nutrition in the selected districts.
The programme will be implemented through a flexible approach, where implementation will be developed and adapted in close collaboration with key actors in existing government structures at national and local level to ensure sustainability. The integrated approach combining efforts of WFP and UNICEF is also expected to improve efficiency, quality and long-term sustainability.
The strengtening of social protection systems and health care systems will be followed by rigorous operational research that will support the implementation and provide qualitative learning for further development of social protection and health care systems. This is expected to support the long-term development of the social protection system and health care system in Uganda.

The overall objective of the programme is to achieve improved community and household resilience among refugees and host populations in refugee-hosting districts of West Nile. The overall objective is broken down into three specific programme objectives: - Improved economic inclusion of households- Improved maternal and child nutrition- Improved maternal, neonatal and child health These objectives are broken down in a number of outcomes on both beneficiary and system levels. Outcome 1.1 - Increased or more secure incomesOutcome 1.2 - Improved access to markets Outcome 1.3 - Improved dietary variation of households Outcome 1.4 - Improved access to health services Outcome 1.5 - Improved health seeking behaviourOutcome 2.1 - More efficient, transparent, child- and nutrition-sensitive social protection systems. Outcome 2.2 - More efficient, transparent, child- and nutrition sensitive health services The programme will deliver a number of results on output level in order to achieve the otcomes and overall objectives. - Support links with on-going Social Protection Programmes- Provide child sensitive household transfers- Support cash transfer mechanisms- Support beneficiary information and assistance management (BIAM)- Support retail markets- Support to feedback and complaints systems- Health system strengthening and support- Social Behaviour Change Communication for increased demand for health services There is also a component on operational research for continuous learning and improvement of social and health services Update September 2020The annual report for 2019 included a proposed revised results framework for the UNICEF-led component. The changes include a revised results nomenclature which in summary changes the semantics to an “Impact, Outcome, Output” structure. Secondly, there is a revision of some of the indicators to better align with the programme design, as well as with UNICEF’s Country Programme Document and approved UNICEF Rolling WorkPlans (2019-2020). UNICEF concludes that "despite the adjustments to the resultsframework, the programme’s implementation framework remains unchanged from what was originally envisioned and submitted by UNICEF in the approved ProgrammeDocument." The changes were approved by Sida in the feedback on the report sent on 29 June 2020 (archived).

description.narrative: IntroductionThe analysis below is based on the annual narrative and financial report for 2019 (Aug-Dec) and follow-up of the implementation during the first half of 2020. The programme document outlined a very detailed/prescriptive list of activities to be carried out in the first year of programme implementation, while at the same time explicitly stating that the programme would apply a flexible approach to implementation. The latter would "allow the programme to pursue its objectives while being able to adapt to emerging developments, risks and opportunities". From the onset of implementation in August/September 2019 it was clear from the initial dialogue with WFP that they wanted to take a step back from the detailed plan for the social protection (SP) component. They proposed to apply their new corporate Country Capacity Strengthening (CCS) approach/methodology, to identify areas of intervention for systems and capacity strengthening. The rationale as described in the annual report is to "ensure a focused approach that delivers results and supports the growth of targeted institutions, to increase their capacity to perform new functions, or achieve more autonomy in continuous tasks. Applying this approach to redefine the focus of system strengthening interventions will contribute to greater sustainability and retention of the capacity developed and strengthened during the programme. One of the fundamental principles of the CCS approach is to be demand-driven and co-created with the institution that receives support." In the very early dialogue stage WFP sought even more far-reaching flexibility and Sida's endorsement to completely remove the transfer component. This was however seen as non-negotiable as it would fundamentally change the original idea of the programme to combine direct targeting of vulnerable refugees and host populations, with system strengthening activities. Being a new approach not only to the programme but also for WFP Uganda, it required time to be internalised by WFP and socialised with national and district government stakeholders, as well as with UNICEF and Sida. The adoption was however presented as instrumental to adjust some of the planned inception phase activities to ensure a robust and sustainable approach to the SP component while still adhering to the overall principles and objectives of the programme. The CCS approach was eventually endorsed by Sida at the kick-off meeting (Sida/WFP/UNICEF) held in November 2019. While introducing a new methodology, many of the planned inception activities are still relevant and have been incorporated within the application of the CCS-approach. The internalization and socialisation processes obviously consumed time not originally planned for. Furthermore the ensuing design process and implementation, requiring buy-in and rigorous consultations with stakeholders, took longer than anticipated. Altogether this resulted in rather substantial delays compared to the original timeline, but the current assessment is that in the end it will have been time worth spending. Summary of key results Component 1: Social Protection (WFP-led)As this component is is entirely new, key results are mostly process oriented and relate to key inception phase activities that lay the foundation for actual implementation of the cash transfers and the system strengthening activities to come. WFP focused on establishing effective partnerships with key stakeholders at national and district level; sharing and consolidating plans for the first year of the programme; and putting in place the team both at central and local levels. Consultations were held with the Ministry of Gender, Labour and Social Development (MGLSD), Office of the Prime Minister (OPM) and District Local Governments (DLGs) of West Nile refugee hosting districts on the joint programme and its objectives through meetings with the District Technical Planning Committee meetings, West Nile Development Association forum, and different Ministry technical briefings. On systems strengthening, the use of the CCS methodology led to the development of a roadmap for the formulation of a multi-year work plan for social protection systems strengthening. The roadmap was presented and agreed with UNICEF and Sida during the first months of the programme. The starting point of the CCS approach is a "capacity outcome statement" that highlights what capacity of which recipient agency is strengthened, by whom, where, how and why. The capacity outcome statement was adopted by OPM, MGLSD and WFP in extensive consultations with the OPM team (NUSAF3 and DRDIP) and MGLSD as the overall statement that will define the capacity needs engagement process. The roadmap outlines how WFP is facilitating government leadership to define the priority areas for intervention years two to five of the project. One critical milestone of this process is the capacity needs mapping that forms the basis to agree priority areas of interventions in a co-owned way. Due to Covid-19 containment measures and limitations to meetings, the consultation process to finalise the capacity needs mapping will be finalised in September (instead of June). WFP is leading the design and implementation of a nutrition- and child-sensitive cash transfer. To maximise linkages between the household transfer and the health system strengthening component, WFP agreed with UNICEF to leverage nutrition services and communication campaigns together with additional resources to support vulnerable households to afford a nutritious diet. Following this agreement, WFP has developed a roadmap to deliver a nutrition-sensitive cash transfer to refugees and host communities in coordination with UNICEF. Much of WFP’s resources will be devoted to the covid-19 reprogramming (see below) for the coming three to four months. During which, a minimal set of originally planned activities that can be done remotely will be worked on with an aim to resume full implementation by the end of 2020. This means that implementation of the cash transfer pilot and social protection system strengthening activities will begin from early 2021. Component 2: Health Package (UNICEF-led)The health package component implemented by UNICEF is to a large degree a continuation/extension of the ongoing project Improving Maternal, Newborn and Child Health through Integrated Approaches, implemented in West Nile, funded by Sida. Hence, this component has moved more straight into the implementation phase including delivery of services to the target population. Examples of outputs:- At the district level, out of an estimated annual burden of 9,430 children with Severe Acute Malnutrition, UNICEF supported the treatment of 4,304 children 6-59 months of age (45 per cent) in West Nile. Out of the total number, 3,273 were from refugee settlements with an average cure rate of 91 per cent. - The project was instrumental to improving the availability and quality of data for decision making. MoH was supported to update and disseminate health information management system (HMIS) reporting tools. Additionally, technical support was provided to DLGs through the implementing partner AVSI to strengthen districts’ capacity for data collection and reporting through HMIS. Across districts, this support has contributed to an average reporting rate of 92% (national average 75%). - To improve water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) in high volume health facilities, 30 health centres were prioritized for WASH upgrades in consultation with DLGs. Construction is ongoing (Sep 2020) and additional improvements are implemented under the other UNICEF contribution supported by Sida. - To address poor treatment outcomes arising from low retention of mother-baby pairs along the Prevention of Mother to Child Transmission of HIV (PMTCT) cascade, 19 Family Support Groups (FSG) were operationalized in Arua, Adjumani, Madi Okollo and Yumbe districts. FSGs are dedicated psychosocial support peer groups for PMTCT mother-baby pairs and their male partners. A total of 707 mother-baby pairs and their male partners with unsuppressed viral loads were identified and enrolled. Building on Sida's earlier and ongoing support to maternal and child health, UNICEF further articulated and initiated the operationalization of the District Health Systems Strengthening (DHSS) approach in all West Nile districts. The approach represents an important shift away from a more traditional one of “health systems support”, where the main emphasis has been on the provision of key inputs to address immediate service delivery gaps. As reported by UNICEF, initial implementation experience suggests that achieving this shift requires a clear strategy and operational approach, supported by sustained communication and resources; clear metrics to assess DHSS effectiveness; and strong partnerships with key stakeholders. Component 3: Cross-cutting (WFP and UNICEF)Cross cutting activities are implemented by WFP and UNICEF. WFP is designing support to local markets in parallel with the design of the nutrition-sensitive transfer, to ensure that a market engagement strategy supports the supply of nutritious food by local retailers. Activities foreseen to support national feedback and complaint mechanisms were absorbed by component 1 and included in the comprehensive capacity needs mapping. UNICEF’s cross-cutting linkages have been integrated into component 2 and progress on operational research includes the launch of a call for proposals to design an impact and economic evaluation of health systems strengthening efforts, and to implement a baseline and produce three to four analytical papers. Impact of COVID-19 and reprogramming of fundsBoth UNICEF and WFP have been affected in various ways, with the government’s containment measures leading to delays in the originally planned programme activities, due to the postponement of gatherings and restrictions to movements. Governance activities were delayed, as well as the development of a multi-year work plan and budget for component 1. As organizations well placed to contribute to the national response and mitigation efforts, both have also received Sida's approval for reprogramming of existing funding to address direct and indirect effects of the pandemic. See below for more information on the reprogramming. UNICEF specificThe approved reallocation of USD 846,000 supports two intervention streams: 1) emergency response for containment and management of Covid-19 (through coordination, risk communication and community engagement, infection prevention and control, mental health and psycho social support, and communication), and 2) the mitigation of the unintended consequences of containment measures (support access to essential services and life-saving goods like, health, nutrition, HIV and WASH). The proposed use of funds is aligned with the National Covid-19 Response Plan for Health Sector and the UNICEF Uganda COVID-19 Response Plan. The risk of Covid-19 negatively impacting the originally planned programme results were assessed by UNICEF as moderate and they commit to minimizing the impact on programme results and notify WFP and Sida if the continued impact of the epidemic jeopardizes expected outcomes. WFP specificThe Embassy was early on in dialogue with WFP about possibilities for reprogramming. The initial plan was a one-off emergency transfer to persons aged 65+ in the West Nile region where the current programme is implemented. It would align with/mirror the existing Senior Citizens Grant (today targeting 80+) and reach both refugees and the host population. The interaction with the government complicated matters however. The dialogue with the line ministry for social protection, Ministry of Gender Labour & Social Development, was constructive but beyond that, social protection was not at the time considered either an essential service or key element of the national response to COVID19. Eventually the Ministry of Finance shut down any proposals put forward by partners that wanted to expand existing programmes horizontally and/or included unconditional cash transfers and chose to focus on labour intensive public works interventions (LIPW) instead. This in spite of overwhelming evidence that unconditional cash is more effective and efficient in an emergency situation. This resulted in a tweaked approach in order to maintain an element of unconditional transfers to support those more at risk of contracting and developing severe symptoms of Covid-19. The approved reallocation of USD 4,2m entails a one-off emergency cash transfer to 117,000 pregnant and lactating women and children under 2 currently covered by three programmes in the refugee hosting districts in West Nile: WFP’s maternal and child health nutrition programme and the government implemented DRDIP and NUSAF labour intensive public works programmes. However, the transfer is delivered by WFP and clearly communicated as an emergency measure. Within the guiding principle of the joint programme, that seeks to align humanitarian response and social assistance, the transfer targets the Ugandan population and refugees with the same demographic characteristics. Given the ration cuts in the humanitarian refugee response, this emergency assistance contributes to the food security of a vulnerable group and will quickly provide financial assistance to a significant proportion of the population. It will reach the groups most in need while leveraging existing government programmes. Importantly, the reprogramming also provides an opportunity to test arrangements and draw important lessons for the planned nutrition-sensitive cash transfer pilot. Financial managementAs a result of underspending in 2019 the 2020 budget was revised in March for absorption of unspent funds. The budget revision was done in close consultation with Sida through several meetings including the project's first Steering Committee meeting that was held in February. An updated multi-year workplan and budget will be presented to Sida in September 2020 for review ahead of the second Steering Committee meeting in October.The next payment of SEK 50,000,000 is planned for September.

description.narrative: Regarding the intervention’s objectives, they are structured at different levels, showingthe way that the change promoted is intended to take. The development intervention's overall objective is to contribute to the improvement of the quality of life of people living in conditions of poverty in three regions of Guatemala, promoting policies and interventions that increase food security, improve livelihoods and increase community capacity to adapt to climate change. Specific objectives: 1) Households in communities in Jutiapa, Zacapa and Guatemala improve their production capacities and adaptation to climate change, through action-research processes and the knowledge and technical assistance generated. 2) Community organizations in proposed communities in Jutiapa, Zacapa and Guatemala improve their organizational capacities and their capacity for proposal and advocacy work, through strengthening and capacity building. 3) Improved risk management and adaptation to climate change at local level in Zacapa and Jutiapa and in municipalities in the department of Guatemala, through the generation and transfer of new knowledge on the environmental situation in these departments. The purpose will be achieved trhough work in four components: (i) In order to fight poverty and hunger in the most arid areas of the country, Component one seeks to increase the capacity of production in systems adapted to climate. (ii) Component two seeks to strengthen citizen participation and advocacy work of leaders (women, men and youth) at local level. (iii) Component three consists in risk management at local level and advocacy onpublic policy. In the climate change risk management, the following is included: a) identification of climate change threats in the three departments considered, b) an assessment of the vulnerability of negative climate change impact in each department, and c) the implementation of regional strategies for reducing the impact of, and vulnerability for, climate change. (v) Component four consists on the proper management and administration of the project is considered. More in detail, this means the adequate technical and administrative managing of the project, the identification of a project base line and an efficient monitoring, follow-up and evaluation of the project results. The beneficiaries of the project are estimated to 3,072 direct beneficiaries and 8400 indirect beneficiaries. The direct beneficiaries are the ones who will benefit from increased agricultural productivity and the acquisition of new agricultural techniques. This group also includes the 72 community leaders receiving training on advocacy. The indirect beneficiaries are those who will receive (but perhaps not incorporate) new agricultural techniques, benefit from the early warning systems constructed within the project and benefit from the increased capacity for political participation and advocacy. The objectives of the intervention are clear and realistic (although ambitious). The logic framework shows the logical relationship among outputs, outcome, impact and the resources that will be invested and the sequence of expected results. According to IARNA, the first year of the project will be crucial to prepare theconditions and alliances needed for the project implementation; thus, during that year,no outcomes will be generated.

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Denna insats kallas för ”Building research-action networks for territorial development and adaptation to climate change”. IInsatsen genomförs i samarbete med Rafael Landívar-universitetet (URL) och dess Institut för miljö, samhällsforskning och planering (IARNA), ett av Guatemalas mest välkända miljöinstitut. Dess moderuniversitet URL är ett privat universitet med campus både i huvudstaden och i flera av landets provinser.
Med den svenska finansieringen kommer IARNA att bedriva forskning om konsekvenserna av klimatförändringarna och lära ut jordbrukstekniker som kan hjälpa människor i fattigdom att klimatanpassa sin matproduktion. IARNA kommer även att utbilda lokala ledare och stärka det lokala civilsamhällets förmåga att påverka beslut på kommunal, regional och nationell nivå, i syfte att motverka miljöförstöring, stärka riskhantering och främja åtgärder för klimatanpassning i offentlig policy. Insatsen kommer genomföras i tre provinser i Guatemala: Jutiapa, Zacapa och huvudstadsprovinsen Guatemala (med omkringliggande samhällen). Dessa provinser präglas, generellt sett, av hög sårbarhet för klimatförändringarnas effekter samt av höga nivåer av fattigdom och undernäring.
Hur ska då dessa resultat uppnås? Insatsens forskningsinriktade del förväntas identifiera åtgärder som är relevanta för att bygga klimatanpassade samhällen och som kan användas i praktiken. Detta förväntas i sin tur bidra till att de småbrukare insatsen riktas mot får bättre och mer klimatanpassade skördar och att målgruppen och dess lokalsamhällen, genom insatsens mer socialt inriktade del, ökad kapacitet att påverka de politiska beslut som berör dem.
För att genomföra detta kommer IARNA att ha forskare och anställda vid institutet till sitt förfogande, liksom annan personal tillhörande Rafael Landívar-universitetet, samt, för delar av arbetet i lokalsamhällena, sistaårsstudenter på universitets agronomprogram. Forskningen kommer att bedrivas och överses av IARNA:s forskare i samarbete med lokalsamhällena. Gällande den jordbruksmässiga och sociala utbildningen så kommer innehållet i olika workshops, hembesök (för jordbruksdelen) och andra aktiviteter att utformas av forskare och IARNA-anställda för att sedan utföras av såväl anställda som utvalda studenter. Många av dessa studenterna är själva lantbrukare vid sidan av studierna och kommer i många fall från de samhällen där insatsen äger rum. De kommer således fungera som en viktig länk mellan universitet och institutet och insatsens målgrupp.
Forskningsresultaten förväntas också kunna användas i IARNAs arbete med påverkan och policyutveckling på nationell nivå, eftersom institutet har renommé och goda kontakter med myndigheter.
Samarbetet med IARNA innebär att Sida i Guatemala inleder ett strategiskt partnerskap med en aktör som kan generera kunskap om klimatanpassning och miljö som är av värde även för andra insatser som Sida stödjer. T.ex. har IARNA genom Sidas försorg redan inlett ett samarbete kring utbildningsinsatser för Åklagarkammaren för miljömål som Sida stödjer genom en annan insats.
Sveriges stöd till insatsen beräknas uppgå till 18,5 miljoner kronor under treårsperioden 2018–2021. IARNA själva medfinansierar insatsen med 4,5 miljoner kronor, vilket innebär en total insatsbudget på 23 000 000 kronor.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The name of this contribution is “Building research-action networks for territorial development and adaptation to climate change”. The contribution will be carried out in cooperation with the Rafael Landívar University (URL) and its Institute of Research and Outreach and Environment and Society (IARNA). This institute is one of Guatemala’s most well-known environmental institutes. The Rafael Landívar University is a private university with campuses both in the capital and in several provinces.
With the Swedish funds allocated to the contribution, IARNA will investigate the consequences of climate change and teach agricultural methods for climate adaptation to people in poverty. IARNA will also educate local leaders and strengthen local civil society’s capacity to influence in decision-making on municipal, regional and national level, with the aim of fighting environmental degradation, improve risk assessments and promote measures on climate adaption in public policy. The contribution will take place in three provinces: Jutiapa, Zacapa and the capital district of Guatemala, including surrounding areas. In general, these areas are marked by a high level of climate vulnerability and, largely, high levels of poverty and malnourishment.
How are these results to be achieved? First, the contribution’s investigative component is expected to achieve scientific results that are relevant for the construction of societies adapted to climate change and that are possible to put into practical use. Secondly, this is expected to improve the yields and the levels of climate change adaption of the small-scale farmers targeted, as well as (through the contribution’s social part) their ability to influence the political decisions affecting them.
For this to be accomplished, IARNA will dispose of the institute’s researchers and employees, other URL staff and, for parts of the field work carried out on community level, last-year student of the university’s Agronomist program. The research will be done and supervised by IARNA researchers in collaboration with local communities. These researchers will also design the contents of the workshops, household visits and other activities included in the agricultural and social parts of the contribution, though some of the activities will be carried out by the students and other staff. Regarding the students, many of them are themselves farmers and, in many cases, residents or natives of the communities addressed by the contribution. Consequently, the students will be an important link between the university and the target group. In total, Swedish support to the contribution is expected to 18.5 million Swedish crowns during the three-year period of 2018-2021. IARNA will co-finance the contribution with 4,5 million crowns, making the total contribution budget 23 000 000 crowns.

description.narrative: The partner (IARNA/Rafael Landivar University-URL) in the first year of implementation of the project focused on creating conditions to implement the project in the coverage areas. Consecuently, reported results are at activities level. This Conclusion on performance will be up dated no later than 31 March 2020, when the first annual progress report has been received. 1) Through a broad call with communities, media, local governments and actors, the project was launched in campus of the URL in Zacapa and Jutiapa, during the event the content and actions of the project were announced. Sida highlighted the importance of cientific reasearch and joint work with the academia, national authorities and community participation on mitigating and adapting to climate change, which is a priority issue for Swidish development cooperation. 2) Through a recruitment process, administrative staff, field technicians, and researcher of the project were hired to work on the three Campus of the URL- (capital City, Zacapa and Jutiapa), at the same time 3 Units of reaserch and agricultural extensions were created. 3) In order to develop a training pensum based on the producers and community leaders priorities and on the environmental conditions, territorial diagnostics were performed in the covered areas. 4) as part of a contractual commitment of the partner, a gender analysis and gender policy were performed. Ulrika Holmstrom Sida's Gender advisor, reviewed the documents and provided inputs which were integrated within the gender analysis and policy. It is important to mention that the integration of a gender perspective in the project is a result of the dialogue between Sida and the partner. Initially the gender approach in the project was very weak. 5) A baseline study is being carried out in the coverage areas, the baseline assessment has a special focus on the environment and gender conditions. 6) As part of the administrative capacity strengthening of the partner and administrative manual and anticorruption and transparency measures for the implementation of the project were prepared. 7) To define early warning systems, two studies on climate hazards were conducted in the coverage areas.

title.narrative: COVID-19 OXFAM Climate Adaptation for Rural Livelihoods (CARL) 2018 - 2021
COVID-19 OXFAM Climate Adaptation for Rural Livelihoods (CARL) 2018 - 2021

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to address COVID-19 New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 In Zimbabwe, the impacts of climate change including extreme events are already being felt among the estimated 1.5 million smallholder farmers whose livelihoods are dependent on agriculture. Higher temperatures, frequent droughts and increasingly heavy rainfall are aggravating the ongoing food insecurity (76% in 2016/17), poverty (76%), stunting (27%), and degradation of agricultural, forest and pasture ecosystems in the more arid Agro-Ecological Regions (AERs) III, IV and V in particular. Nowhere is this more evident than in the vulnerability “hot-spots” of Buhera (Manicaland Province), Gutu (Masvingo Province) and Bulilima (Matabeleland Province) districts. Failure to adapt to climate change may cause the rural sector and smallholder farmers to fall further behind in terms of Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). The Climate Adaptation for Rural Livelihoods (CARL) in Zimbabwe project’s Theory of Change is premised on the belief that the capacity of rural households to absorb, adapt or transform in the face of increasing climate risk can be improved if there are changes in their access to a combination of livelihood assets at household (micro), watershed (meso) and national (macro) levels. The goal of the CARL project is to improve the well-being of Zimbabwe’s rural population and reduce poverty and food insecurity in the face of climate change. The underlying project development objective is to improve the climate resilience of agricultural production and rural livelihoods for 6,000 households in Buhera, Gutu and Bulilima Districts of Zimbabwe. This will be achieved through three interrelated outcomes, (i). Targeted vulnerable communities increase adoption of climate resilient livelihoods and agricultural production systems; (ii). Rural women and youth in targeted vulnerable districts increase their income and economic power in sustainable agriculture value chains, and (iii). Support institutions have strengthened technical capacities to address mitigation and adaptation concerns of rural livelihoods.
The CARL project will use Climate Resilient Villages and associated micro-watersheds as entry points to combine the scaling up of existing successful practices with innovations and new pilots in areas where needed. The scaling up will be achieved by leveraging financing from government, farmers, the private sector (including the financial sector) and other development partners that share Oxfam’s ambition to reduce rural poverty through increased climate resilience and productivity.
Beneficiaries
The project will directly benefit 6,000 households (25,200 women, men, youth and children) from 16 wards in Buhera (6 wards), Gutu (5 wards) and Bulilima (5 wards) districts. Of these, the project will deliberately target 1500 women (500 from each district) and 300 youths (20 from 15 wards. In Bulilima only 4 wards will be targeted since youths there tend to be too mobile) for enterprise development to support some of the resilience building interventions. The Climate Resilient Village and integrated watershed management approach used in this project requires the participation of all households in the targeted villages. The target groups are households currently dependent primarily on dryland farming. The main source of income for the farming community is crop and livestock sales, while for the wider community it is mostly casual labour and petty trade. The major source of income and livelihoods for most of the people in the target area is agriculture. The project will increase revenue opportunities, financial services, reduce malnutrition, and increase social cohesion.
The second group of beneficiaries are national agricultural research and extension institutions, the Meteorological Services Department, Zimbabwe National Water Authority and Rural District Councils that will receive technical capacity building support in integrative land use mapping and planning, catchment management, climate information services for farmers and water resources management, and establishment of field-based learning platforms for piloting agricultural innovations on climate change adaptation and mitigation. Policy makers will also benefit from knowledge generated to inform policy.
Project Management
The CARL project will be implemented by Oxfam in Zimbabwe in partnership with Southern Alliance for Indigenous Resources (SAFIRE), University of Zimbabwe and technical support from the Swedish Meteorological Hydrological Institute (SMHI) for capacity building of the Zimbabwe Meteorological Services.
Geographical Coverage
The CARL programme will target communities in Agro-Ecological Region III, which is not currently being covered by Sweden’s contribution to the Zimbabwe Resilience Building Fund. Targeting this area will help to ensure that the Embassy is covering the most vulnerable beneficiaries in rural Zimbabwe through a combination of resilience and adaptive programming.
Expected impact
The project is expected to increase income for the rural poor, agricultural productivity and climate resilience of supported households including women and youth in the targeted districts. Benefits are expected to derive from: (i) increased productivity and production at the farm level through adoption of a package of innovative climate-adapted production practices; (ii) increased access to livelihood assets, including renewable energy, technologies and financial services for micro and small enterprises (MSEs) and women and young entrepreneur businesses related to supporting sustainable growth of targeted value chains; (iii) increased capacity of institutions at the macro level to provide relevant climate risk information for agriculture and water resources management. The project will contribute towards SDGs 1, 2, 5, 13 and 15.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Bland de 1,5 miljoner småbönder i Zimbabwe märks konsekvenserna av klimatförändringarna av tydligt. Jordbruket är deras inkomstkälla, och högre temperaturer, frekvent torka och alltmer kraftigt regn försämrar livsmedelssäkerheten i landet. I distrikten Buhera (Manicaland), Gutu (Masvingo) och Bulilima (Matabeleland) är detta extra tydligt. Misslyckande att anpassa sig till klimatförändringarna kan leda till att landsbygdens småbönder får det ännu svårare att nå FNs Globala mål.
Stödet till projektet ”The Climate Adaptation for Rural Livelihoods” (CARL) i Zimbabwe förväntas bidra till att hushållen på landsbygden ska kunna anpassa sig till de nya klimatförhållandena, genom tillgång till bättre försörjningsmöjligheter på hushålls- (micro), flodområde- (meso) och nationell nivå. Målet med CARL-projektet är att förbättra livskvaliteten för Zimbabwes landsbygdsbefolkning, minska fattigdomen och säkra livsmedelssäkerheten inför kommande klimatförändringar. Det underliggande projektutvecklingsmålet är att förbättra klimatbeständigheten för jordbruksproduktionen och dess försörjning för 6 000 hushåll i distrikten Buhur, Gutu och Bulilima. Detta kommer att uppnås genom tre resultatområden (i). Utsatta samhällen ökar antagandet av klimatbeständiga jordbruksproduktionssystem och därmed försörjningsmöjligheter. (ii). Kvinnor och ungdomar på landsbygden i utsatta områden ökar sin inkomst och ekonomiska makt i värdekedjor för hållbart jordbruk, och (iii). Stödinstitutionerna har stärkt teknisk kapacitet för att stötta klimatanpassningen bland de utsatta områdena på landsbygden. CARL-projektet kommer att använda ”Climate Resilient Villages” för att nå ut till fler byar, detta genom lånefinansiering från regering, bönder, privat sektor, och andra biståndspartners som delar Oxfams ambition att minska fattigdomen på landsbygden genom utökat stöd för klimatbeständighet och produktivitet.
Förmånstagare
Projektet kommer att gynna 6 000 hushåll (25 200 kvinnor, män, ungdomar och barn) från totalt 16 kommuner i distrikten Buhera (6 kommuner), Gutu (5 kommuner) och Bulilima (5 kommuner). Av dessa kommer projektet avsiktligt att riktas mot 1500 kvinnor (500 från varje distrikt) och 300 ungdomar (20 från 15 kommuner, i Bulilima kommer endast 4 kommuner att vara med eftersom ungdomar tenderar att flytta) för företagsutveckling för att stödja några av de resiliensbyggande insatserna. The Climat Resilient Village med dess flodområden som används i detta projekt kräver deltagande av alla hushåll i de utvalda byarna. Målgruppen är hushåll som idag är beroende av torrmarker för sitt jordbruk. Den främsta inkomstkällan för bönderna är försäljning av skörd och boskap, medan det för resten av samhället ofta är småhandel och tillfällighetsarbete som är den största inkomstkällan. Överlag är den största inkomstkällan jordbruk i dessa områden, och projektet kommer öka inkomstmöjligheter, finansiella tjänster, minska undernäring och öka social sammanhållning.
Den andra gruppen av förmånstagare är institutioner som Meteorological Services Department, Zimbabwe National Water Authority och kommunalråd på landsbygden. Dessa kommer att få stöd i teknisk kapacitetsuppbyggnad för kartläggning och planering, avrinningshantering, klimatinformationstjänster för bönder samt hantering av vattenresurser. Man kommer även att upprätta plattformar för att kunna utveckla nya uppfinnigar som kan stödja och utveckla jordbruket inför kommande klimatförändringar.
Projektledning
CARL-programmet kommer att genomföras av Oxfam i Zimbabwe i samarbete med Southern Alliance for Indigenous Resources (SAFIRE), University of Zimbabwe och tekniskt stöd från Sveriges meteorologiska hydrologiska institut (SMHI) för kapacitetsuppbyggnad av Meteorological Services of Zimbabwe.
Geografisk täckning
CARL-programmet kommer att riktas mot samhällen i vad som kallas Agro-Ecological Region III, vilka i nuläget inte omfattas av stöd från Sida genom Zimbabwes Resilience Building Fund. Att inkludera detta område kommer att bidra till att ambassaden täcker de mest sårbara förmånstagarna på landsbygden i Zimbabwe genom en kombination av resiliensbyggande och anpassningsbar programmering.
Förväntad inverkan
Projektet förväntas öka inkomsterna för landsbygdens fattiga (särskilt kvinnor och unga), samt jordbruksproduktivitet och klimatresiliens. Fördelarna förväntas komma från: (i) Ökad produktivitet och produktion på hushållsnivå genom antagande av ett paket med innovativa klimatjusterade produktionsmetoder; ii) Ökad tillgänglighet av försörjningstillgångar, inklusive förnybar energi, teknik och finansiella tjänster för småföretag, kvinnor och unga företagare för att stödja en hållbar tillväxt. iii) Institutionernas ökade kapacitet på makronivå för att ge relevant information om klimatrisken av jordbruks- och vattenresursförvaltning. Projektet kommer att bidra till SDG 1, 2, 5, 13 och 15.
CARL-programmet fokuserar i första hand på klimatförändringar med målet att skapa mer motståndskraftiga samhällen (område 3.1), interagera användningen av produktiv förnybar energi (område 3.2) och genom sammankopplingar till marknader och finanser kommer det att bidra till att skapa gröna jobb och inkomst för några av de mest utsatta i Zimbabwe, särskilt kvinnor och ungdomar (område 3.1). Dessutom behandlar den miljöförstöring och främjar en helhetlig vattenförvaltning och hållbarhet (område 3.3). Programmet integrerar även genus i varje aspekt av sin programmering (område 1.3).
Ambassaden bedömer att den föreslagna insatsen uppfyller kraven i strategin för utvecklingssammarbete 2017-2021 och kommer att bidra till att skapa en portfölj som är holistisk när det gäller miljö, klimatförändring, resiliens och förnybar energi.

The project development objective is to improve climate resilience of agricultural production and rural livelihoods in Buhera, Gutu and Bulilima districts through concrete on-the ground vulnerability reducing and adaptive capacity building investments, knowledge support and technical capacity building of supporting institutions. The specific objectives of the project are: 1. To reduce vulnerability of the smallholder agriculture production system to climate impacts through developing and implementing a matrix of vulnerability reducing and adaptive capacity building measures in 16 model Climate Resilient Villages (CRVs) in Buhera, Gutu and Bulilima districts for the benefit of 6,000 households. 2. To enable 3000 rural women and 1000 youth to expand their economic opportunities and income from more efficient and inclusive agri-food value chains in groundnuts, Michigan pea bean, sugar beans, mung bean, honey, cattle and goats. 3. To build the capacity of relevant supporting institutions to address climate adaptation and mitigation information requirements for the targeted vulnerable rural areas. 4. To share information and learning on the implementation of climate change adaptation for sustainable socio-economic development in Zimbabwe. The intended outcomes and specific outputs include: Outcome 1: Targeted vulnerable communities increase adoption of climate resilient livelihoods and agricultural production systems. Output 1.1: A range of gendered innovative natural resources management and climate resilient agricultural systems incubated and tested in the CRVs in target districts. Output 1.2: A minimum of 10,000 hectares of the watershed in the CRVs restored/protected to improve food security and livelihoods using the natural ecosystem. Output 1.3: 5000 farmers in the 16 CRV villages adopt a range of gendered technologies and practices that enhance the drought resilience, production and income of their crop production systems. Output 1.4: 1000 Livestock farmers in the 16 CRVs adopt a range of gendered technologies and practices that build the drought resilience, production income of the livestock production system. Output 1.5 Innovative climate risk management institutional arrangements established/strengthened in each CRV. Outcome 2: Rural women and youth in targeted vulnerable districts increase their income and economic power in sustainable agriculture value chains. Output 2.1: 120 Village Savings and Lending Groups established in the three districts and reaching out to 3000 women and youth. Output 2.2: - 900 youth and 1500 women benefit from a range of “green” agri-businesses opportunities in private sector supported value chains in the 16 CRVs in the targeted districts. Outcome 3: Support institutions have strengthened technical capacities to address mitigation and adaptation concerns of rural livelihoods. Outputs 3.1: 60 rain gauges and 10 community suitable water level sensors installed in the sub catchment areas in which the 16 CRVs are situated. Output 3.2: Meteorological Services Department capacities to generate and disseminate meteorological and climate information for agriculture and water resources management improved. Output 3.3 Decision making tools/Matrix for climate risk management in agriculture and water resources developed and tested in the CRVs. Outcome 4: Increased awareness and replication of adaptation measures. Output 4.1: Project M&E system developed, implemented and providing adaptive feedback to support effective project management. Output 4.2: Knowledge and communication products related to rural livelihoods resilience produced and disseminated with the target districts, at national and international levels.
